awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Stability and Dynamics of Antarctic Marine Outlet Glaciers
awd_abstract_narration:
Van der Veen/1543530

The objective of this research is to gain better understanding of the West Antarctic ice flow in the transition region from grounded ice to floating ice shelves and investigate the conditions that can initiate and sustain major retreat of these glaciers. Several major Antarctic outlet glaciers and ice streams will be investigated using a suite of observational techniques and modeling tools. Glaciers include Thwaites Glacier, which has become a focal point in the discussion of West Antarctic retreat, Whillans Ice Stream as an example of the archetype ice stream, and Byrd Glacier, a major outlet glacier draining East Antarctica through the Transantarctic Mountains into the Ross Ice Shelf.  This study will investigate whether the ongoing changes in these glaciers will lead to long-term mass loss (the onset of ice sheet collapse), or whether these glaciers will quickly stabilize with a new geometry.   

To adequately incorporate the dynamic behavior of outlet glaciers and ice streams requires inclusion of the relevant physical processes, and the development of regional models that employ a numerical grid with a horizontal grid spacing sufficiently refined to capture smaller-scale bed topographic features that may control the flow of these glaciers. This award revisits the issue of stability of marine-terminating glaciers whose grounding line is located on a retrograded bed slope. In particular, an attempt will be made to resolve the question whether observed rapid changes are the result of perturbations at the terminus or grounding line, or whether these changes reflect ice-dynamical forcing over the grounded reaches. High-resolution satellite imagery will be used to investigate ice-flow perturbations on smaller spatial scales than has been done before, to evaluate the importance of localized sites of high basal resistance on grounding-line stability. This collaborative project involves a range of modeling strategies including force-budget analysis, flow-band modeling, Full Stokes modeling for local studies, and using the Ice Sheet System Model developed at JPL for regional modeling. Broader Impacts include training two graduate students in computer simulations and ice sheet modeling algorithms. The work will also expand on a web-based interactive flowline model, so that it includes more realistic grounding line dynamics.

por.por_cntn:
This work addressed a major unresolved glaciological question: do changes observed on marine-terminating glaciers represent short-lived adjustments to external forcings, or do these changes signify the onset of sustained collapse of marine portions of the Antarctic Ice Sheet? The hypothesis to be tested was that gradients in longitudinal stress are unimportant to the large-scale flow and stability of marine glaciers and that observed accelerations and retreat are not the result of release of ?back stress? or other perturbations at the grounding line or calving front, but rather the result of ice dynamical forcing in the lower reaches (e.g. changes in effective basal pressure resulting in increased ice discharge and associated thinning).

To answer these questions we adopted a multi-disciplinary approach that has evolved somewhat over the course of the project. In particular, the focus of research changed from being on the Antarctic Ice Sheet to the Greenland Ice Sheet.

As noted in the proposal, a ?universal? sliding relation has not been established. To investigate the form of the sliding relation, we compiled data for 100+ Greenland outlet glaciers for which sufficient data are available to test the commonly adopted sliding relation in which the velocity at which the ice slides over the bed is proportional to the friction at the bed, and inversely proportional to effective pressure at the bed (the difference between the weight of the ice column and the water pressure in the subglacial hydraulic system). Our results show that there is no significant correlation between basal drag and sliding speed. The effective pressure was found to be inversely related to sliding speed with. Repeating the analysis for 125 glaciers in Antarctica, a similar result was found.

After confirming that our analysis is consistent for both Greenland and Antarctic glaciers, we conducted numerical experiments using the ISSM model and found the model results are show a marked insensitivity of sliding speed to basal drag variations. This suggests that sliding on glaciers is described by what is called Coulomb Friction, with basal friction limited to some upper bound for sliding speeds in excess of 500 m/yr or so. This of course has important implications for numerical ice sheet models which continue to rely on the ?old? sliding law.

A second line of investigation concerned to relation between calving events and glacier velocity. To objectively evaluate the interaction between glacier calving and ice discharge we conducted a statistical analysis of 25 outlet glaciers in Greenland that underwent significant retreat over the period 1999-2018. Our analysis failed to show a significant correlation between change in terminus position and glacier discharge, casting doubt on the conclusion expressed by others that mass loss of the Greenland Ice Sheet is driven by glacier retreat. An investigation using the concept of Grainger causality also failed to show that terminus retreat causes ice discharge to increase. In other words, calving events do not appear to be driver of glacier acceleration, even on short time scales.
